resource.chars:
[paragraph]1 <u>Introduction<\u> 
<u>Ovibos Moschatus<\u>, more commonly known as the Msk Ox 
of North America, has been described by naturalists under 
varios names, as their opinions fluctuated <s>regarding<\s> concerning its 
affinities with the Oxen Buffaloes or Sheep. It is 
called the Boeuf Musqu[e acute] by its original discoverer 
in Hudsons Bay M. Jeremie, (1) by Drage (2), Dobbs (3), Ellis (4), Hearne (5) 
and all the arctic explorers of the present <s>day<\s> century. 
Under this name it was first systematically described 
by our countryman Pennant (6), who also gives an admirable 
figure of the male and female and by Buffon (18). It is described 
under the name of <u>Bos Moschatus<\u> by Gmelin (7), Zimmermann 8 
Schreber (9), Blumenbach (10), Shaw (11) and Cuvier (12), <s>who however<\s>, the 
latter however rendering it in French Le Buffle 
Musqu[e acute]. M. de Blainville (13), on the other hand, considers 
the animal intermediate in character between the 
sheep and the ox proposed the name <u>Ovibos Moschatus<\u> 
which was adopted by Desmarest (14), Sir John Richardson (15), 
and more lately by the great French Palaeontologist 
M. Lartet (16), while Professor Owen (17), considers the term 
"Misguiding" and believes that the animal has been 
subgenerically separated without due grounds from 
the other Bubali, and especially from the Cape 
Buffalo, Bubalus Caffer, and therefore figures and 
describes the animal under the name of Musk 
Buffalo. To settle this conflict of opinion as to
